statement:
Let $L/K$ be a finite Galois extension with Galois group
$G = \operatorname{Gal}(L/K)$. The modern formulation of Hilbert’s
Theorem 90 states that the first Galois cohomology group $H^1(G, L^*)$
is 0.

The original statement of Hilbert’s Theorem 90 differs somewhat from the
modern formulation given above, and is nowadays regarded as a corollary
of the above fact. In its original form, Hilbert’s Theorem 90 says that
if $G$ is cyclic with generator $\sigma$, then an element $x \in L$ has
norm 1 if and only if $$x = y/\sigma(y)$$ for some $y \in L$. Note that
elements of the form $y/\sigma(y)$ are obviously contained within the
kernel of the norm map; it is the converse that forms the content of the
theorem.
